column4: Hello folks.  I need help getting SNMP setup and configured.  Would that be here or another channel?
more than just installing the packages?
there are several reasonable hits just googling for ubuntu snmpd.
they mostly degenerate into: apt-get install snmpd snmp snmp-mibs-downloader, and then fixing /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf and /etc/snmp.conf
the operative word here is "correctly"
by default the snmp agent will answer to v2c requrests with community string "public"
the comments in /etc/snmpd.conf are also reasonably helpful.  But there is so much policy going on that it is tough to know what is right for any given site.
the easiest way to get started is to read through the comments in /etc/snmpd.conf and set the community string to something other than public.
then try to talk to the agent using "snmpwalk -v2c -c public"
ah! does the agent respond to simple requests?
and do you get a response when you use the public address?
then it seems like the agent is configred properly.
do you get symbolic oid in the responses? or just a list of dotted numbers?
pastebin is blocked from where I'm sitting.  go figure.
when you run "snmpwalk -Of -v1 -cpublic your.host.name | grep ipNetToPhysicalTable" should be the arp table
if you want the symbolic values.
in /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf the line that starts "rocommunity" decides what is visible with community string "public"
if you make a line "view plummerb included .1.3.6" then "rocommunity plummerb default -V plummerb"  you'll get the full tree if you use plummerb as the communtity string.
you'll also have to restart snmpd for the above to take effect.
I'd expect something like that to work.  Or to trim your rocommunity line down to just the .1.3.6 oid
the key in the vew lines is to allow different groups of managers to have visibility of different oid subtrees.
that's proibably because your snmpwalk can't find the mib files.
if you want the symbolic oid then you need to add snmp-mibs-downloader package and comment out the mib: line in /etc/snmp/snmp.conf (note no "d")
sorry. walked away.  the mib files have documentation inside them.
